This is an old and very tricky issue I'd like to eliminate. It is tricky because it happens only for users with a clean system, and will gone as soon as they change their font defaults or install another font. 

In summary, some sites looks ugly for Linux users, while others looks better. It caused because the system font selection is defaults to a serif font, while the default serif font for these users contains large letters and doesn't looks right. For other sites it never happens, as they are using a CSS rule to use sans-serif fonts.


Steps to reproduce:
a, Get a CLEAN Ubuntu system, with no Microsoft Core Fonts installed and no other font setting changes in the system or the application (A clean Ubuntu virtual machine should be great).
b. Go to www.ynet.co.il in order to see the bad serif font used.
c. Go to www.tapus.co.il in order to see a better font selection.


Expected result:
Better default fonts for Hebrew on sites such as ynet.co.il. Users should not be required to change default fonts or install more fonts in order to see Hebrew in a readable font.
comments.author: tomer.moz.bugs@tomercohen.com
